p: The present study provided a reasoning and reassurance for the uses of A. graveolens for medical purposes. The methanolic extract of A. graveolens (AG-ME) showed significant antioxidant efficacies as observed by total antioxidant, DPPH radical scavenging, H 2O 2, and ferrous reducing capacities. As it can be seen from this investigation, A. graveolens may be used as a good supply of natural antioxidants through probable nutrition supplement. AG-ME also showed a dose-dependent strong anticancer/cytotoxic potential against MCF-7, A-549, and HeLa cell lines. It further exhibited oxidative stress-mediated ROS production and loss of MMP in MCF-7 cells. A dose-dependent increase in the activities of caspase-3 and caspase-9 suggests that the AG-ME-induced MCF-7 cell death is caspase-dependent. Additional investigation is required to examine biological and anticancer activities under in vivo system to discover possible beneficial use of AG-ME against diseases.
